bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941

div1.p: Truby comments on Dean, Ames, Carroll and Agramonte. He feels his memory is sound, though he knows Hench has some skepticism. He offers his recollections of Carroll's infection and his attitude towards the mosquito theory.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, September 3, 1941

opener.dateline:
145 Laurel St
S. F. Calif
Sept 3/41

div1.p:
I am returning herewith your mms.
on Mr Bullard's Experiences in Cuba, and
the photos of the painting- Unfortunately I can't
find the 1st page of the Bullard story but
it may turn up later- Sorry-
I have also made a few notes on the
data from the Medical History which may be
of some interest. When you get my mms. you
will see that I have covered some of the
points brought out about the buildings
reported by May Brown. What I said about them was
all from memory and it is nice to have
this confirmation- Thanks for the copy
of Lazear's death certificate. Other important
thingdocuments to search for are the originals of the sick
and wounded reports from Aug. 1900 to
March 1901- The offical data, all “checked
and double checked”, will be found there
of every case from Dean's first illness on. Ames'
illness in Jan. (I think) will be found
also, with a possible diagnosis of
yellow fever. That report would have
Starks' signature. I was sure that Ames
was immune. He said he was and was
hired as such for yellow fever work.
I have always questioned the story that Ames
had yellow fever at that time.

Thanks for the photo of the Loretcha Hotel.
It is the same old building- A barn
of a place perhaps, but they did have a
good cafe-

I was glad to have your comment on
my remarks on the Hemmeter photostats.
your silence (no letters) for several months
made me feel that my frank and,
no doubt, very surprising statements therein
had in some way offended you an made
you think that my opinions were most
unsound. They were my honest and sincere
conclusions made in 1900 and more or less
confirmed by the controversies later. Carroll
was a most efficient worker, but he had to
be led by a man with vision, like Reed-
I firmly believe you will eventually find
that most of my statements are based on
facts. I usually have had “both feet on the ground”
I think and have been a fairly good judge
of human frailties. Anyway my opinions
were only intended for you, in order to let
you have the best possible insite on the
situation as I saw it. In my mms. I
have carefully followed the views developed
by our correspondence and with those of Kean
& Ireland- Perhaps I have been too
generous with Carroll & Agramonte-
Personally I have no reason to write
anything against them for publication.

My big object in everything I have written
is to acquaint you with all the information
I have so that you can really have the facts
Ac
T
3
as I saw them. Of course I know
that you have been sceptical of some of
the things I have written, but many
of those statements have, I feel sure,
been confirmed by your investigations.
I realize that my memory is not
infallible, but in most things that
impressed more me in my younger
days, I think it is quite reliable.
For recent events, it is worthless-
Sclerotic changes!

There is no doubt about Building
no 1. It is the same old structure.
The thing you will have to look out
for now is to secure it against
those frightful tropical hurricanes that
strike Havana in Sept. Oct. & Nov.
It is liable to blow away like the
other one did unless it is protected
in some way- The storm I experienced
there in Oct. 1906 was the worst one
I encountered. Trees, G. I. roofing
and many buildings were blown down-

Thanks for the offer to let me read
Dominguez' book. I don't think I want
to read it now. Sometime later I may
ask you to let me see it.

I will be delighted to see you out
here in Feb. or March- We will have
a grand time if you can stay long
enough to make it worth while-

That grand child of mine was
born the night I wrote you. If I had
not mailed the letter about 10 that evening
and held it until morning I could have
told you about it. It is a little girl
and all doing nicely.

In your Cleveland talk there are a few
errors I think. on p. 5. the Board saw
date on Agramonte's P of Sc M article p 219
Finlay early in July (not Aug 1) and Lazear
& Reed actually were at work with mosquitoes
(which they developed from eggs & Larvae given
them by Finlay) during my visits in July-
I am sure about that. When Durham
By July 16.
& Meyers were there (exact date unknown)
in July they saw the mosquitoes in the lab-

Carroll was only bitten once and
that was on Aug 27 and by one
mosquito only. He did not believe in
the theory but he also was approved to being
a “guinea pig,” Pinto will tell you this
I am sure- Carroll did not take
post in the tests between aug 11 and 25.

I have not had time to really go over the
story carefully- Hope you can read
this badly written letter. Am in a hurry.
